SENT.plain: Background: Mutations in genes encoding the L-type cardiac calcium channel (LTCC) are associated with various types of inherited arrhythmias, including Brugada syndrome (BrS)
However, the frequency in Asian populations remains unknown

This study aimed to elucidate disease-causing mutations in LTCC-related genes in Japanese patients diagnosed as BrS or idiopathic ventricular fibrillation (IVF), early repolarization syndrome, short QT syndrome, and compare them with those carrying SCN5A mutations
Methods and Results: We screened CACNA1C and CACNB2b in 312 probands and compared the clinical characteristics between probands with gene mutations in CACNA1C or SCN5A
In results, we identified 6 CACNA1C mutations in 7 unrelated probands and SCN5A mutations in 20 probands
There were no CACNB2b mutation carriers
In topology, half of the mutations were located in the C-terminus
Among 7 CACNA1C mutation carriers, 2 were female and 3 were symptomatic; 2 patients were resuscitated from ventricular fibrillation, and 1 patient had syncope
Compared with SCN5A mutation carriers, there were no significant differences in the ECG characteristics
2 of 3 symptomatic CACNA1C patients were female, but all female SCN5A mutation carriers remained asymptomatic
Conclusions: We identified 6 CACNA1C mutations in BrS and IVF patients and their phenotypes were varied
Although mutation frequency was not high, screening of LTCC channel genes may be clinically important to prevent unexpected sudden death
